stream_context.summary: Kaze prototypes a comedic seesaw setpiece (a breakable box triggers a plank to tip and eventually squash a Goomba), then stress-tests a large industrial/factory level on real N64. The stream centers on console performance triage (backface culling, geometry trimming, collision-map plans) and a real hardware crash caused by a division-by-zero that the compiler unexpectedly executes via a MIPS branch delay slot. He also shares practical business/creator context (why he streams on Kaze Clips, sponsorship ending, YouTube profitability) and begins planning a construction-worker Womp variant.
stream_context.significance_reason: Major N64-compatibility checkpoint: real-hardware crash diagnosed (delay-slot division-by-zero), and a concrete optimization strategy (N64-only backface culling + mesh trimming, collision-map pending) measurably improves FPS in a high-poly level.

findings.summary: Real N64 testing surfaced a floating-point exception caused by division by zero in ClipMario—an area Kaze had edited—turning into a must-fix hardware bug rather than an emulator-only quirk.
findings.quote: Floating point exception… in ClipMario. It’s actually a function I’ve edited, so… this might be a real bug I need to fix.

findings.summary: The division-by-zero persisted even after an apparent code fix because the compiler scheduled the divide into the branch delay slot, effectively executing it unconditionally. Kaze worked around this by restructuring computations to avoid unsafe instructions being pipelined into delay slots.
findings.quote: The compiler decided… to pipeline the division into the delay slot of my branch. So that no matter what happens, I always divide by 0.

findings.summary: Kaze validated a major console performance lever: enabling backface culling on specific “metal” materials (likely only on N64) improved worst-case views from ~19 FPS to ~25–29 FPS, making a huge scene acceptably playable on hardware.

He is building platform-specific rendering behavior: he prefers the look with backface culling off on emulator, but will enable it on N64 for performance (and even notes it can look better on real hardware).

The large factory level’s scale is quantified: ~13,000 polygons with on-screen text; ~6,000 without text, helping frame the optimization problem and why certain camera angles are the true bottlenecks.

He identifies additional optimization avenues not yet applied: deleting unseen underside geometry, removing unnecessary transform nodes (wasted matrix multiplies), adding a collision map to reduce collision processing cost, and possibly reorganizing areas if console load becomes too heavy.

Setpiece design: a breakable box triggers a seesaw/plank to fall; Kaze iterates to make the motion readable, deterministic, and funny—aiming to end with the plank pinning/squashing the Goomba in a visually satisfying final pose.
findings.quote: We only need to fake it well enough that no one notices that it’s fake.

findings.summary: He emphasizes player readability: he rejects ideas that would obscure when a star will appear, because existing levels rely on having a clear marker/telegraph for star spawns.

World/lore drift: the area began as “Bozo’s Fleet Factory” but evolved toward a general “refueling/tanking up” location; Kaze isn’t sure airships will appear there later, but expects a narrative beat where Bozo is angry Mario destroyed his airships.
Level-structure stance: he’s fine with interconnected worlds in theory, but prefers separate courses with overworld-only connections, criticizing Banjo-Tooie-style interconnection for backtracking.

Kaze explains channel strategy: he streams on Kaze Clips (10k subs) rather than a smaller channel or the main channel to avoid algorithm damage and to keep streams focused on game-dev viewers rather than broad-audience commenters.
findings.quote: My streams here… are all about the game. If you get entertained, that’s a side effect—I just care about making a good game.

findings.summary: Financial reality check: he says the channel is “barely profitable” and notes that the Brilliant sponsorship deal ended after six videos, putting him “back to square zero” for that income source.
findings.quote: My YouTube channel is barely profitable, especially now that Brilliant doesn’t sponsor me anymore—kind of back to square zero.

findings.summary: Platform target clarity: the mod uses the N64 Expansion Pak; he believes the game doesn’t currently fit into 4MB, though it might be possible with significant extra work (separately loaded areas/codes) that he views as low payoff.

Pipeline dependencies: Zeina has already produced (most) animations for at least one new character/enemy; Kaze expected music from Badub but notes Badub has been absent recently, creating uncertainty for audio direction/timing.

biobak.summary: Biobak tracks Kaze’s “fake physics” approach as an intentional production choice, reinforcing the idea that the seesaw motion is more animation than simulation.
biobak.quote: Real-time simulation physics for the YouTube clip, namely.

badub.summary: Kaze had been expecting Badub to contribute a song (and later agrees audio/sound design can be handled near the end), but says Badub has been missing, leaving music plans uncertain for the moment.

zeina.summary: Kaze credits Zeina with having made the animations (all or most) for a character/enemy he’s checking in the build, indicating asset readiness on animation for that element.

findings.summary: Lilaa pushes for making star spawns readable/telegraphed and offers general implementation feedback during the seesaw and star-marker discussion, which Kaze aligns with due to existing level design dependencies.

key_stories.title: Real N64 crash traced to compiler delay-slot division by zero
key_stories.summary: While testing on real N64, the game throws a floating-point exception in ClipMario—a function Kaze modified—forcing a deep dive into why a seemingly guarded divide still executes. The resolution reveals how compiler scheduling into MIPS branch delay slots can make “safe” code unsafe on hardware, and why emulator behavior can mask critical bugs.
key_stories.challenge: An N64-only crash (floating point exception) persists even after Kaze adds logic intended to avoid division by zero.
key_stories.process: Kaze reproduces the failure, inspects the code path, and realizes the compiler moved the division into the branch delay slot so it runs regardless of the branch condition. He restructures the computations to force safe scheduling and recompiles for another hardware test.
key_stories.outcome: The team gets a clear explanation for the crash and a concrete workaround strategy, plus a reinforced need to verify critical paths on real hardware (since emulators may not surface the issue).
key_stories.key_quote: That’s not a bug in the code. That is not my fault.

key_stories.title: Factory level performance triage: N64-only backface culling and geometry cuts
key_stories.summary: Kaze tests a massive industrial scene on real N64 and finds worst-case views dropping to ~19–22 FPS. Instead of shrinking the level’s ambition, he identifies rendering-cost culprits (lack of backface culling, unnecessary unseen triangles) and applies targeted, platform-specific optimizations.
key_stories.challenge: The level’s scale and sightlines produce low FPS on N64, risking playability and forcing an optimization plan.
key_stories.process: He measures polygon counts, compares performance hotspots by camera angle, enables backface culling on key materials, and discusses removing undersides/hidden faces and adding a collision map to reduce CPU collision processing.
key_stories.outcome: Backface culling alone raises worst-case performance to ~25–29 FPS, making the level “playable” on hardware while preserving higher-fidelity visuals on emulator where he prefers culling off.

key_stories.title: Designing a readable ‘squash the Goomba’ seesaw gag
key_stories.summary: Kaze prototypes a setpiece where breaking a box causes a plank to tip, bounce, and pin a Goomba—aiming for comedy and clarity rather than perfect physics. The iteration shows his approach to making scripted moments feel physical, predictable, and communicative to the player.
key_stories.challenge: A dynamic object needs to fall convincingly, not clip through walls, and end in a clear, funny tableau while remaining deterministic enough for gameplay.
key_stories.process: He adjusts rotation/acceleration behavior, adds constraints and state changes (detach Goomba after tipping threshold), tests edge cases (Mario riding it, camera angles), and tweaks speed/slide to sell weight without breaking control.
key_stories.outcome: The motion reads well and the final pose is “beautiful,” but he still needs to finalize Goomba squish detection and polish (sounds, minor motion tweaks).
key_stories.key_quote: The final image is beautiful… it ending like this is the best thing ever.

key_stories.title: Creator tradeoffs: algorithm protection, sponsor loss, and project sustainability
key_stories.summary: Kaze explains why he quarantines dev streams on Kaze Clips and avoids the main channel: protecting the algorithm and keeping the audience aligned with game development. He also mentions a concluded sponsorship deal and low profitability, hinting at the economic pressure behind development pace and streaming choices.
key_stories.challenge: Balancing discoverability and income with the need for a focused, low-noise development space and sustainable time allocation.
key_stories.process: He chooses a secondary channel for streams, keeps the main channel’s content tightly curated, and acknowledges sponsorship cycles ending (six-video deal completed).
key_stories.outcome: A clearer picture emerges of why releases are hard to forecast and why the stream space is intentionally niche and craft-first.
key_stories.key_quote: I don’t want to ruin my algorithm.

open_questions.topic: Preventing and detecting delay-slot / scheduling hazards across the codebase
open_questions.context: The ClipMario crash showed the compiler can schedule unsafe operations (like division) into a branch delay slot, making a guard ineffective on N64.
questions: After discovering this delay-slot scheduling issue, did you add any coding guidelines or patterns to avoid similar hazards elsewhere?
How do you audit for other ‘looks safe in C, unsafe in assembly’ cases—especially in performance-critical math and collision code?
Did this change how often you test on real N64 versus relying on emulators during day-to-day iteration?

open_questions.topic: Defining an N64-versus-emulator visual policy (backface culling, fog, draw distance)
open_questions.context: Kaze prefers backface culling off on emulator for visual reasons, but enabling it on N64 dramatically improves FPS (and can even look better on hardware).
questions: What’s your guiding rule for when a visual difference between emulator and hardware is acceptable versus when it breaks the ‘authentic N64’ promise?
Will players be able to toggle any of these performance/visual tradeoffs, or will it be fully automatic per platform?
How do you test that these N64-only changes don’t affect gameplay readability (e.g., scaffolding bars disappearing)?

open_questions.topic: Impact of a missing audio collaborator on production planning
open_questions.context: Kaze expected Badub to deliver music but says Badub has been absent; later he agrees sound design will be done near the end when the sound budget is clear.
questions: When Badub is unavailable, what’s your fallback plan—temp tracks, another collaborator, or shifting the schedule?
How late can you realistically leave sound design before it starts affecting level design and feedback (telegraphs, comedy timing, atmosphere)?
What parts of audio do you want Badub to own versus what you’ll implement yourself (mixing, triggers, per-surface footstep set, etc.)?

open_questions.topic: Consolidating parallel repos and build targets
open_questions.context: Kaze notes he must fix the same bug in two repos (Return to Yoshi’s Island and Only Up 64), which he says he hates because it doubles maintenance effort.
questions: What’s the long-term plan to avoid duplicated engine fixes across repos—shared submodules, cherry-pick workflow, or merging common code?
How often do ‘side project’ prototypes (like Only Up 64) generate fixes that you later backport into Return to Yoshi’s Island, and is that worth the overhead?
Did this incident change how you decide whether to prototype in a separate repo versus inside the main project?

open_questions.topic: Designing the ‘five people you mess with’ mission structure in the factory area
open_questions.context: Kaze outlines a plan for multiple NPC/encounter beats (Goomba, cement guy, oil barrels, etc.) but says he still needs to brainstorm how the player ‘messes with’ some of them, especially oil barrels.
questions: Who are the five ‘people’/targets in this sequence, and what’s the intended emotional arc—comedy, cruelty, workplace satire, escalation?
What makes the oil-barrel interaction hard compared to the cement guy—technical constraints, readability, or just not finding the right gag yet?
How do you keep these scripted interactions from feeling like one-off jokes and instead make them feel like a cohesive mission?
